item.description:
Keybindings or keyboard shortcuts are essential to an efficient workflow. They help you navigate faster, be more productive and reduce the time you spend on repetitive tasks.

My workflow is heavily keyboard driven and primmarily relies on a browser and a terminal within a tiling window manager, for these I use my own set of keybindings. Because I work on multiple machines and operating systems, I have to keep track of all the keybindings I use and make sure they are somewhat consistent across all the systems and tools.

ls parsing bad, do this

ls -1iq | grep -o '^ *[0-9]*' # get file inodes
find /path/to/search -inum <inode_number> # convert inodes to file info

You still here? (thanks!! ğŸ˜‡) ok, then read on:

Do you know why its not recommended to parse ls output for operation on a list of files? It’s because the UNIX system allows any characters in filenames so things like newline, whitespaces, ~ (and a lot more weird chars) are all valid.

item.description:
What is this

Posh2K is a prompt for oh-my-posh, it works on all shells, has multiple segments with aesthetically pleasing colors.

Inspiration

Most of my workflow is based on the command line, recently I had to use a Windows system for some work and was really displeased by the CLI experience.

So, I needed a prompt that can work across shells and has support for different segments and Posh2K was born.
